;;因在《魔女嘉莉》和《骗子》中获得奥斯卡提名的角色而闻名的派珀·劳瑞 (Piper Laurie) 去世，享年 91 岁。 ;

;派珀·劳瑞 (Piper Laurie) 是一位意志坚强、获得奥斯卡提名的演员，尽管一度完全放弃演艺事业去寻找“更有意义”的生活，但她仍出演了广受好评的角色，周六凌晨在洛杉矶的家中去世。她享年 91 岁。

;

;劳里 (Laurie) 因年老去世，她的经纪人马里昂·罗森伯格 (Marion Rosenberg) 通过电子邮件告诉美联社，并补充说她是“一位才华横溢的人，也是一个了不起的人”。

; < p>;劳瑞于 1949 年以罗塞塔·雅各布斯 (Rosetta Jacobs) 的身份来到好莱坞，很快就与环球国际公司签订了合同，这是一个她讨厌的新名字，并与罗纳德·里根 (Ronald Reagan)、罗克·哈德森 (Rock Hudson) 和托尼·柯蒂斯 (Tony Curtis) 等人一起出演了一系列主演角色。

; >; ;

;她随后凭借三部不同的电影获得了奥斯卡金像奖提名： 1961 年台球室戏剧《骗子》； 1976 年史蒂芬·金的恐怖经典电影《魔女嘉莉》的电影版；以及 1986 年的浪漫剧《小上帝的孩子》。她还在电视和舞台上出演了多个广受好评的角色，包括 1990 年代大卫·林奇的《双峰》中饰演邪恶的凯瑟琳·马泰尔。

;

;劳里 (Laurie) 制作了17岁时，她在《路易莎》中首次亮相，扮演里根的女儿，然后在《弗朗西斯去赛马》中与会说话的骡子弗朗西斯演对手戏。她与曾经约会过的柯蒂斯一起拍了几部电影，包括《小偷王子》、《新郎无处可去》、《阿里巴巴之子》和《约翰尼·达克》。

;

;厌倦了之后，她拿着 2,000 美元走了出去。 - 1955 年的一周合同，发誓除非提供像样的角色，否则她不会再工作。

;

;她搬到了纽约，在那里她在戏剧和现场电视剧中找到了她想要的角色。< /p>;

;

;在《酒与玫瑰的日子》、《聋子的心》和《追寻之路》中的表演为她带来了艾美奖提名，并为她重返电影铺平了道路，其中包括在《骗子》中饰演保罗·纽曼陷入困境的女友这一广受好评的角色。

;

;多年后，劳里不再从事演艺事业。她与电影评论家约瑟夫·摩根斯坦结婚，生下了女儿安·格蕾丝，并搬到了纽约伍德斯托克的一座农舍。她后来说，民权运动和越南战争影响了她做出改变的决定。

;

;“我不再抱有幻想，正在寻找一种对我来说更有意义的存在，”她回忆道，并补充说，她从来没有后悔了这一举动。

;

;“我的生活很充实，”她在 1990 年说道。“我总是喜欢用手，而且我总是画画。”

;

;劳里也因面包师，她的食谱出现在《纽约时报》上。

; ;

;那段时间她唯一的表演是与十几位音乐家和演员一起参加的参观大学校园，支持参议员乔治·麦戈文 1972 年的总统竞选。

;

;当导演布莱恩·德·帕尔玛打电话给劳瑞，让她在《魔女嘉莉》中扮演茜茜·斯派塞克精神错乱的母亲时，劳瑞终于准备好重返演艺圈。

; >;

;起初她觉得这个剧本很垃圾，然后她决定自己应该扮演这个搞笑的角色。直到德·帕尔玛斥责她在场景中加入了喜剧性的转折，她才意识到他的意思是这部电影是一部惊悚片。

;

;《嘉莉》票房大卖，引发了关于青少年陷入困境的电影的热潮，斯派塞克和劳瑞双双获得奥斯卡金像奖提名。

;

;劳瑞重新燃起演艺欲望，重新开始了长达数十年的忙碌职业生涯。在电视上，她出演了《马特洛克》、《谋杀案》、《她写作》和《欢乐一家亲》等电视剧，并在《急诊室》中扮演乔治·克鲁尼的母亲。

; Sun, 15 Oct 2023 08:22:01 +0800 Stephen Rubin, book publisher for John Grisham and Dan Brown, dead at 81https://www.theguardian.com/books/2023/oct/14/stephen-rubin-book-publisher-dead-john-grisham-dan-brown
;;2023-10-14T22:59:34Z;
;
;;棕褐色色调的脚本特写，上面写着“达芬奇密码”。
;

;Stephen Rubin一位长期担任出版业高管，着眼于畅销书，对音乐和公共生活充满热情，曾帮助约翰·格里沙姆等人开启了职业生涯，并发行了《达芬奇密码》和《火与怒》等大片，现已去世。他享年 81 岁。

;

;鲁宾的侄子戴维·罗特 (David Rotter) 表示，鲁宾因“短暂而突然的疾病”于周五在曼哈顿的一家医院去世。

;

;如果没有鲁宾，很难想象图书出版业的发展。声音沙哑的鲁宾，几十年来一直是一个强大而多彩的形象，戴着玳瑁眼镜，穿着时尚的西装，结识了从杰奎琳·肯尼迪到贝弗利·希尔斯的各种各样的朋友和同事。他在西区宽敞的公寓里举办了令人难忘的派对，也是八卦的主要来源，对朋友、同事和更广阔的世界时而做出亵渎的评价，时而充满爱意的评价。 ” 密友、哈珀柯林斯出版社前首席执行官简·弗里德曼通过电子邮件告诉美联社。 “他有非常强烈的好恶，并且他;从未;改变主意。”

;
;
;

;他会进入一个房间并立即填满它。他有非常强烈的好恶，并且从未改变主意

;
; ;Jane Friedman;
;
;
;

;鲁宾是前纽约人泰晤士报记者，于 20 世纪 80 年代涉足出版业，并在 Doubleday（肯尼迪曾在 Doubleday 担任编辑）和亨利·霍尔特公司 (Henry Holt and Company) 中晋升到高层职位。最近，他担任 Simon & 出版社的出版顾问。舒斯特。

;

;鲁宾的许多著名项目包括比尔·奥莱利和马丁·杜加德的销量百万的《杀戮历史》系列、劳拉·埃斯基维尔的《巧克力之水》、米奇·阿尔博姆的《与莫里的星期二》、希拉里·曼特尔的《带上尸体》和前总统乔治·W·布什 (George W Bush) 的《决策点》(Decision Points) 是鲁宾在布什在出版界及其他领域广泛不受欢迎的时候帮助签署的又一百万畅销书。

;

;图书高管梦想着监督甚至一种现象。鲁宾至少得分三次。

;

;20 世纪 90 年代初，他刚刚在 Doubleday 开始工作，当时出版商准备发行一位名不见经传的作家约翰·格里沙姆 (John Grisham) 的惊悚小说。小说《公司》使格里沙姆成为法庭戏剧的代名词，并标志着他和鲁宾之间长期友谊的开始。

;

;“史蒂夫·鲁宾是一位伟大的出版商，”格里沙姆在一份声明中说。 “他喜欢书，尤其是畅销书排行榜上的书，而且他知道如何将它们带到那里。他是作家的梦想——忠诚、慷慨，而且从不羞于表达自己的观点。他很少犯错，但从不怀疑。”

;
;
;

;他是作家的梦想——忠诚、慷慨，从不羞于表达自己的观点

;
; ;约翰·格里沙姆;
;
;
;

;十年后，道布尔戴接手了一位当时默默无闻的作家，他的《西蒙与约翰》的销量很少。但舒斯特现在有了一份很有前途的手稿，这是一部以欧洲为背景的宗教/艺术惊悚片。通过不懈的促销活动，包括向书商和其他业内人士发送数千份预印本，丹·布朗的《达芬奇密码》立即引起了持久的轰动。尽管一些评论家和其他作家鄙视它，一些宗教官员认为它亵渎神灵，但该书的销量还是突破了 7000 万册。 《恶魔》和《数字堡垒》也成为畅销书。

; ;

;“史蒂夫对我的作品充满感染力的热情是每个作者的梦想，”布朗在一份声明中说。 “史蒂夫是一位世界级的品酒家，他常常给我寄来几箱奢华的意大利葡萄酒——他开玩笑说，这是一个秘密阴谋，目的是让我拥有精致的味觉，这样我就永远无法停止写作。我永远感激他的信念、他的鼓励，最重要的是他的友谊。”

;

;2018 年，鲁宾 70 多岁的时候，他又经历了一次非凡的旅程。他是《霍尔特》的出版商，也是特朗普总统任期内的一本签名书《迈克尔·沃尔夫的火与怒》的监督人，鲁宾在两年前与这位经验丰富且经常引起争议的记者喝鸡尾酒后同意接手这本书。

;

;《火与怒》是第一部生动地捕捉政府持续混乱的作品，事实证明它是如此不讨人喜欢，以至于特朗普威胁要阻止其出版，并解雇了与沃尔夫交谈过的高级助手史蒂夫·班农(Steve Bannon)。鲁宾称这本书是他职业生涯中“最狂野的经历”。

;

;鲁宾来自纽约，他最初和持久的热情是音乐，尤其是歌剧。从纽约大学毕业后，他获得了波士顿大学新闻学硕士学位。

;

;Rubin 在 20 世纪 80 年代中期加入了老牌平装书出版商 Bantam Books，并在那里工作了六年，然后前往 Doubleday 。自始至终，他始终保持着对歌剧和古典音乐的热爱，并与 2010 年去世的妻子辛西娅 (Cynthia) 一起帮助管理旧金山音乐学院的鲁宾音乐批评研究所，这是一个值得骄傲的事情。

;

;他知道书籍将定义他的遗产，尤其是销量最多的书籍。在他的回忆录中，他做出了一个简洁但不完整的预测：“我想我讣告的标题会是：‘《达芬奇密码》的出版商去世了’。”

; Sun, 15 Oct 2023 07:22:01 +0800 New Zealand hold off Ireland in titanic battle to reach World Cup semi-finalshttps://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/oct/14/ireland-new-zealand-rugby-world-cup-quarter-final-match-report
;;2023-10-14T21:05:30Z;
;
;;新西兰的乔丹和亚伦·史密斯会拥抱
;

;痛苦仍在继续。爱尔兰一定想知道他们必须做些什么才能打破这个四分之一决赛的魔咒，作为世界第一要花多长时间，要赢得多少个大满贯，有多少场连胜。让记录表明：八次四分之一决赛，八次失败。

;

;现在的全黑队：九次四分之一决赛，八次胜利。新西兰最近遭受了怎样的痛苦，一段时间以来，新西兰一直是椭圆形领域的冠军。这对他们来说可能并不意味着重返巅峰，但那种熟悉的精准、防守中的顽强、对胜利的渴望已经重新获得。

;
;

;;相关：;< a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/live/2023/oct/14/ireland-v-new-zealand-rugby-world-cup-2023-quarter-final-live-score-updates" >;爱尔兰对阵新西兰：2023 年橄榄球世界杯四分之一决赛 – 直播;

;
;

;在他们清醒之后;揭幕战中被法国队击败;，新西兰队遭遇很少在他们余下的台球比赛中，他们的抵抗方式。他们通过一系列的展览适时地找到了自己的步伐。在这里，在四分之一决赛中处于不熟悉的劣势地位时，他们保持了我们所熟知的精确度。爱尔兰队看起来很匆忙。

;

;他们在四分之一决赛中的记录可能一直在他们的脑海中浮现，但在他们自己的精确表现与强大的;苏格兰队;在最后一轮泳池比赛中，爱尔兰队出奇地松了。

;

;争边球误入歧途，传球到地面。在对阵全黑队的比赛中做到这一点，你很快就会发现自己以 13-0 落后。确实如此。两粒点球，一粒是里奇·莫翁加的，另一粒是乔迪·巴雷特在中场罚下的，让新西兰队早早取得领先。然后是辉煌。

;

;巴雷特兄弟中的另一位博登将一颗辉煌的碎片射入太空，并收集起来。球以闪电般的速度传给了莱斯特城的Fainga'anuku，后者找到了Rieko Ioane。后者的内线回球速度如此之快、灵巧，就连法因加阿努库接到球时一定感到惊讶，但他反应过来将球接了过来。

; ;

;所以新西兰队早早以 13-0 领先，就像 2007 年在卡迪夫的四分之一决赛中，法国队恢复状态后将他们淘汰出局一样。我们都知道当时的裁判是谁，韦恩·巴恩斯（Wayne Barnes）在早期的比赛中当然更倾向于全黑队，但随着爱尔兰队以他们在世界排名第一的信心做出回应，这种情况开始发生变化。约翰尼·塞克斯顿在比赛重新开始后就罚进了一个点球。六分钟后，他完成了他们的第一次尝试。

;

;马克·汉森（Mack Hansen）在左路与丹·希恩（Dan Sheehan）交换传球，然后塞克斯顿（Sexton）和詹姆斯·洛（James Lowe）长传球找到了邦迪·阿基（Bundee Aki），后者上前击球。他穿过五名防守队员到达罚球线。也许船已经恢复了。

;

;唉，爱尔兰队在半场休息前几分钟又错过了一次争边球，威尔·乔丹打出一记致命一球，以 50-22 帮助全黑队进入第二场比赛，当阿迪·萨维亚（Ardie Savea）在角落里工作时。但爱尔兰在中场休息前有时间做出回应。

; ;

;亚伦·史密斯故意击倒汉森的内线球，为他赢得了一个在罪箱中的咒语。爱尔兰两次获得角球，贾米森·吉布森-帕克从争边球的一侧绕过，在中场休息时将爱尔兰队追回18-17。

;

;第三节全是爱尔兰队。他们只是落后了一些。所需要的只是一个错误，或者一个魔法的闪现，任何一方都可以争论到底是哪一个。爱尔兰队向新西兰队发起了惯常的进攻，但萨维亚阻止了最新一球，赢得了点球。一场干净利落的争边球，一场由莫翁加表演即走的比赛，还有一个巨大的空档等待他突破。爱尔兰不会原谅自己放任定位球。莫翁加不在，他把乔丹逼到了角落。

;

;爱尔兰人当时一定很绝望，但他们还是继续来。最后，当他们在最后一节开始几分钟后将比分追至一分之差时，一切终于揭晓了。爱尔兰赢得点球，塞克斯顿将球罚入角球。科迪·泰勒（Codie Taylor）在争边球中拉倒了球——点球并吃到一张黄牌。

;

;巴恩斯再次支持新西兰队，特别是在争球中，他为全黑队三比零找到了机会。乔迪·巴雷特 (Jordie Barrett) 错失了一次这样的点球，但不久后他就击中了目标，在比赛进入最后 10 场时拉开了 4 分的领先优势。

;

;爱尔兰队再次施压。又一个点球获胜，另一个点球被送入角球。例行公事如常进行，这次是对阵七人小组。不知何故，乔迪·巴雷特(Jordie Barrett)潜入了前进的狼群下面。新西兰队再次坚守。

; ;

;现在只有尝试才能赢得它。爱尔兰开始了最后的围攻，阶段又阶段，进入红色分钟后，毫不留情地晋级到22点，观众几乎悬念地低声嘀咕。最后一击，最后一击全黑队老将萨姆·怀特洛克（Sam Whitelock），越过了球。爱尔兰人的梦想结束了。全黑霸主地位恢复。

; Sun, 15 Oct 2023 05:22:02 +0800 Scientists build traps to manage UK’s rising number of Chinese mitten crabshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/14/scientists-build-traps-to-manage-uks-rising-number-of-chinese-mitten-crabs
;;2023-10-14T20:08:23Z;
;
;;中华绒螯蟹
;

;被自然保护主义者列为100种最严重外来入侵物种之一在世界上。现在，一群科学家希望他们找到了一种方法，可以消灭英国快速增长的中华绒螯蟹种群，并防止这种甲壳类动物“吃掉我们”，这种甲壳类动物可以长到比 10 英寸餐盘还大，并拥有独特的毛茸茸的爪子。 ”。

;

;该小组在林肯郡的 Pode Hole 建造并安装了英国第一个中华绒螯蟹陷阱，以捕捉这些贪婪的捕食者，当它们迁徙到下游交配时。

;

;“大闸蟹正在吃我们的本土动物群，”自然历史博物馆的保罗·克拉克博士说，他是该项目的科学家之一。 “如果我们开始捕获这些螃蟹并消灭它们的数量，我们可能会看到我们的环境发生更好的变化。”

;

;这可能包括当地的刺泥鳅数量的增加，据报道，这是一种淡水鱼波德厅的数量减少了，水田鼠、双壳类软体动物、小虾和蜗牛也随之减少。

;

;中华绒螯蟹，因其起源于东南亚而得名，最初是在英国发现的1935 年。此后人口激增。

;
;

;;相关：;;野猫在苏格兰高地被释放，以防止英国的灭绝;

;
;

; Sun, 15 Oct 2023 02:22:01 +0800 ‘Ring of fire’ visible in parts of US as crowds gathered to watch annular eclipsehttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/oct/14/ring-fire-eclipse-visible-states-us
;;2023-10-14T17:25:21Z;
;
;;A maybe 5-year-old white boy holds black floppy sunglasses across his eyes with both hands as he peers at the sky.
;

;As the “moment of annularity” was reached, photos were snapped, crowds cheered and the sky darkened – in the areas that the annular solar eclipse could be seen, at least.

;

;Annularity during a solar eclipse is the moment when the moon is fully in front of the sun, creating the ring of fire that is the visual highlight of today's eclipse. It lasts for only a few minutes.

;

;The direct path of the eclipse covers portions of eight states from Oregon to Texas, although at least a partial eclipse, minus the ring of fire, ;was visible; in all 41 of the other continental states including Alaska.

;
;

;;Related: ;;What is an annular solar eclipse and where will the 'ring of fire' be visible?;

;
;

;Nasa kept up with a ;livestream of the event;, including views from telescopes in its track. Gasps and cheers could be heard as ;annularity was reached; in Albuquerque, New Mexico, where the space agency was viewing the eclipse. “We're in annularity. It is a gorgeous sight to behold,” said Michael Kirk, a heliophysicist at Nasa.

; ;

;An annular eclipse is one in which the moon passes between the sun and Earth, but at or close to its farthest point from the planet. It appears smaller than the sun and does not completely cover it, producing the image of a dark disk on top of a larger, brighter disk and creating the effect of a fiery ring around the moon.

;

;In remote corners of the country, eclipse watchers were up early, or had camped overnight, to try to get the best view possible. At Bryce Canyon national park in southern Utah, lights were visible before sunrise along a well-known trail that snakes through a valley of red rock hoodoos.

;

;“I just think it's one of those things that unites us all,” said John Edwards, a cancer drug developer who traveled alone across the country to try to watch the eclipse from Bryce Canyon. “It's seeing these unique experiences that come rarely is what got me here. This is about as rare as it gets.”

;

;The most recent annular eclipse visible in North America was in 2012. The next viewing opportunity will be in 2039 in Alaska, and 2046 in the lower 48 states.

;

;Eclipse festivals and watch parties were taking place at numerous planetariums, science museums, schools and other venues across the country.

;

;Nasa had urged a ;safety-first approach;, warning people not to look at the event except through special eclipse glasses, a solar viewer, or solar filters on a telescope. The space agency recommends alternative, non-direct viewing methods, such as a pinhole projector.

;

;Scientists also used the occasion to study how a sudden drop in sunlight affects the upper atmosphere. Three Nasa “sounding rockets” were ;fired into the shadow of the eclipse; from the White Sands missile range in New Mexico to record atmospheric changes.

;

;After an earlier pass above Alaska, the annular eclipse was visible in central and southern Oregon beginning at approximately 9.13am PT, and followed a south-east path across portions of California, Nevada, Idaho, Utah, Arizona and New Mexico, before crossing a wide expanse of Texas and into the Gulf of Mexico.

;

;The Yucatán peninsula, and several Central and South American countries from Belize to Brazil also lie in the path of annularity.

;

;

;Wales led 10-0 through a Dan Biggar try, conversion and penalty, only for Boffelli to wipe out that deficit with four penalties during a damaging spell either side of half-time.

;
;

;
;

;The scrum-half Tomos Williams's try, again converted by Biggar, put Wales back in front. ;Argentina had laboured to qualify from their group, but they made a bright start in perfect conditions by stretching Wales's defence. ;Anxiety had rippled through Welsh ranks when Biggar went down clutching his chest after tackling Santiago Chocobares, but he quickly resumed following treatment.

;

;Wales' problem area was the lineout, losing two on their own throw inside the opening 25 minutes, but Argentina could not take advantage with the Pumas making little headway following an impressive start.

;

;Biggar then missed a penalty, but Boffelli was more accurate with successive kicks as the first half ended with Argentina on the attack and growing in confidence until an overtime brawl broke out with the Pumas just 10-6 behind.

;

;Prior to Boffelli's second successful strike, the Wales wing Josh Adams was fortunate to avoid a yellow card for pushing over an Argentina player off the ball, and a half-time substitution saw hooker Dewi Lake replace Ryan Elias.

;

;Argentina retained the initiative after half-time, and Boffelli completed a quickfire penalty hat-trick that send further warning signals to a Wales team that had temporarily lost its way. ;Tomos Williams made an instant impact after going on for Gareth Davies, splitting open Argentina's defence on a weaving 25-metre run to the line. Biggar's conversion put Wales back in front, holding a five-point lead approaching the hour mark.

;After Petti's let-off, Sclavi pounced following sustained pressure before Boffelli's conversion put Argentina back in front and Wales were once again in trouble. ;

;It was a breathless and frenzied finale – a suitable end to a memorable contest – before Sánchez intercepted Sam Costelow's pass, Boffelli converted, Sánchez landed a penalty and Wales were out.

; Sun, 15 Oct 2023 00:22:02 +0800 ‘It was a plague’: Killarney becomes first Irish town to ban single-use coffee cupshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/14/it-was-a-plague-killarney-becomes-first-irish-town-to-ban-single-use-coffee-cups

;
;;College Street in Killarney, County Kerry
;

;Killarney used to accept it as a price of being a tourist town: ubiquitous ;disposable coffee cups; spilling from bins, littering roads and blighting the ;area's national park;.

;

;The County Kerry town went through about 23,000 cups a week – more than a million a year – adding up to 18.5 tonnes of waste.

;

;Not any more. Three months ago, Killarney became the first town in ;Ireland ;to ;phase out single-use coffee cups;. If you want a takeaway coffee from a cafe or hotel, you must bring your own cup or pay a €2 deposit for ;a reusable cup; that is returned when the cup is given back.

;

;The results are evident in bins, which now seldom overflow, and on streets and forest trails where it is rare to see abandoned cups.

;

;“It was a plague on the town and countryside,” said Michael Gleeson, chair of the group Killarney Looking Good, that promotes civic improvements. “This was a wonderful and necessary initiative. The amount of cups strewn around is considerably reduced.”

;

;On a stretch of the N22 road to Cork, Gleeson used to pick up five or six cups, now he tends to find just one, if any.

;

;Other Kerry towns, including Tralee and Dingle, are considering emulating the experiment, and the hope is that it will spread across Ireland and beyond, said Gleeson. “Our great challenge is to make our world more beautiful.”

; ;

;Eliminating single-use cups sounds a relatively modest goal but only a handful of other towns, such as ;Freiburg; in Germany, are known to have tried similar initiatives. The people behind Killarney's campaign know why – it's not easy.

;

;“We were looking at options for community projects, and we thought, 'Oh, coffee cups, that'll be quick',” said Louise Byrne, a sustainability manager for the Killarney Park Hotel and The Ross.

;

;“Oh, were we wrong,” said Ciara Treacy, another hotel manager. “It takes a lot of work, and it doesn't stop. People think we're the coffee cup police. We're not. We have jobs.”

;

;Pilot projects in other places faltered because participating cafes discovered that customers migrated to cafes that continued offering disposable cups, said Treacy. “The minute you give consumers the choice, they'll take the convenience.”

; ;

;The campaign sought to enlist all of Killarney's 21 independent cafes, a lengthy process of individual face-to-face meetings, research, negotiations, a town hall-style gathering, a video, and more discussions.

;

;In addition to environmental benefits, the organisers said cafes could save money – each disposable cup costs 20 to 30 cents – and enhance Killarney's brand.

;

;Still, some cafe owners worried about forfeiting their stocks of single-use cups and alienating local customers as well as tourists. Eventually, nearly all signed up, and a credit union donated €5,000 for marketing, paving the way to the launch on 31 July. “If it can be done in Killarney, at the height of the tourist season, it can be done anywhere,” said Killian Treacy, of Luna Deli + Wine.

;

;More than 50 local businesses are now on board, including a factory that told staff to bring only reusable cups to work.

;

;“It's a great idea,” said Paul McClure, 43, visiting from San Diego. He had no objection to paying a €2 deposit for a takeaway cup that could be returned to any cafe in Killarney or 400 locations across Ireland, including Dublin airport, that are part of a wider campaign.

;

;Thorunn Einarsdottir, sipping a flat white, said the scheme could work in her native Iceland. “It's really smart. It's like learning to organise your trash – it's habit.”

; ;

;Replicating the scheme in cities would require government intervention because not every cafe would voluntarily sign up, said Killian Treacy. The Irish government's planned 20-cent tax on disposable coffee cups, known as the latte levy, is a start, but not enough, he said.

;

;Killarney cannot take success for granted – businesses need regular reassurance and updates, said Ciara Treacy. “There is a lot of hand-holding.”

;

;At least one holdout remains. “We have a big stock of disposable cups to use up,” said Elaine Leahy of Noelle's cafe, which has stayed out of the scheme. That has had a knock-on effect on a neighbouring cafe, Rí-Rá, which has resumed using single-use cups as well as reusables.

;

;Byrne is confident the scheme will continue to expand with help from community leaders and schools. “We can't save the world but each of us can make a little change.”
